bestBHT.bht: Jesus forewarns his disciples about the trials they will face after his departure, contrasting their knowledge with the ignorance of the world. He wants them to remember what they are suffering for and to be prepared for the challenges ahead. Being forewarned is being forearmed. They must lay up in their minds what they have heard and put it into practice, as they will encounter conflicts and endure suffering. Jesus assures them that these tribulations were appointed by God and foretold by him.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, Jesus tells his disciples that he is forewarning them about the trials that they will face once he is gone, in contrast to the ignorance of the world. He wants them to remember and have knowledge of what they are suffering for, as he knows well what they will have to endure. This is a new declaration that Jesus is making in reference to his imminent departure, because he was with them before. He wants them to be prepared for the difficulties that will come their way, as being forewarned will help them be forearmed. Though he had spoken about these things early on, he reminds them again to drive the point home. He wants them to remember and lay up in their minds what they have heard, as they will be required to put them into practice. He wants them to be prepared for the conflicts that they will face and also to bear their sufferings with patience, as they were appointed by God and foretold by him. Jesus did not fully reveal the circumstances and the object of his death and ascension to heaven earlier, as his presence with them was like the presence of the Holy Spirit that would be with them after his departure. He wants them to know that they will be taking his place and that his trials were their trials, which he had not explicitly told them before. So, he is now repeating these things to them so that they can have a fresh insight into the mystery of the Cross and be fully prepared for what lies ahead.

Jesus forewarns his disciples about the trials they will face after his departure, contrasting their knowledge with the ignorance of the world. He intends for them to remember what they are suffering for, as he understands their burdens. This warning is new in reference to his impending absence, as he had not spoken so explicitly before. Jesus wants them to be prepared for the challenges ahead, taking solace in the fact that being forewarned is being forearmed. He emphasizes the importance of remembering and putting into practice what they have heard, as they will need to face conflicts and endure suffering with patience, all of which were appointed by God and foretold by Jesus himself. Ultimately, Jesus wants them to be equipped to take his place and, in doing so, fully comprehend the mystery of the Cross.
